classrooms, and 400 pupils. “There are several
dozen youngsters here with whom we never have
an attendance problem,” principal John Formby
says. “They get their lunches free, and if they
miss school, they miss their main meal of the day. ’ ’
Beneath Formby’s homespun drawl are thirty
years of vigorous service to education. At one
time he served as a consultant for the U. S. Gov¬
ernment on rural education in Brazil. After
World War II, he staged a one-man invasion of
Washington. Buttonholing his Senator and mov¬
ing the complex machinery of Air Force surplus-
material disposal, he obtained several truckloads
of machinery with which to establish a vocational
program at Holtville High School that is now a
model throughout the state. When ETV came
along, Formby seized upon it and aroused local
interest. “Folks in Marbury work hard, and we
don’t have much spare time or money for civic
activities,” says Formby. “This is a poor com¬
munity without even a Lions or Rotary Club. But
Marbury managed to be first in the county to buy
television sets for its school. The money was raised
by a barbecue. Chicken, milk, and even a Coke
machine were donated. The fathers went out and
caught enough fish to feed everyone twice over.
“My teachers are hard-working, but you can’t
expect them to teach math, Spanish, science, and
English equally well. ETV has given them the
assistance of a highly trained staff of educational
specialists to help enrich classroom instruction.”
